Question
========
Consider linear discriminant analysis model with two classes and two explanatory variables $x = (a, b)$. 

The model is given by
$$
(x \mid y=1) \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mu_1; \Sigma \right), \quad (x \mid y=2) \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mu_2; \Sigma \right), \quad \mathbb{P(y=1) = `r p1`},
$$
where 
$$
\mu_1 = \begin{pmatrix}
0 \\
0
\end{pmatrix}, \quad
\mu_2 = \begin{pmatrix}
`r mu2a` \\
`r mu2b` \\
\end{pmatrix}, \quad
\Sigma = \begin{pmatrix}
`r sigma11` & `r sigma12` \\
`r sigma12` & `r sigma22` \\
\end{pmatrix}.
$$

Find the line $k_a \cdot a + k_b \cdot b = 1$ that separates the two classes, ie 
any point on the line has equal conditional probabilities to be in each class. 

Provide the ratio $k_a / k_b$ as the answer with 2 decimal digits.
